The **2018–19 NBA season** will be the 73rd season of the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA). The regular season will begin on October 16, 2018, and
end on April 10, 2019. The playoffs will begin shortly after, with the NBA
Finals concluding in June. The [2019 NBA All-Star Game](/wiki/2019_NBA_All-
Star_Game "2019 NBA All-Star Game") will be played on February 17, 2019, at
the [Spectrum Center](/wiki/Spectrum_Center_\(arena\) "Spectrum Center
\(arena\)") in [Charlotte, North Carolina](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina
"Charlotte, North Carolina").

## Transactions

Main article: [List of 2018–19 NBA season
transactions](/wiki/List_of_2018%E2%80%9319_NBA_season_transactions "List of
2018–19 NBA season transactions")

### Retirement

  * On May 10, 2018, [Nick Collison](/wiki/Nick_Collison "Nick Collison") announced his retirement from the NBA. Collison played all his 15 seasons with the [Seattle SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics")/[Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder") franchise.[1]
  * On May 25, 2018, after playing 13 seasons in the NBA for seven teams, [Mo Williams](/wiki/Mo_Williams "Mo Williams") announced his retirement from the NBA to take the assistant head coaching job at [Cal State Northridge](/wiki/Cal_State_Northridge "Cal State Northridge").[2]
  * On July 17, 2018, after playing 10 seasons in the NBA for four teams, [Roy Hibbert](/wiki/Roy_Hibbert "Roy Hibbert") retired from the NBA.[3]
  * On August 27, 2018, [Manu Ginóbili](/wiki/Manu_Gin%C3%B3bili "Manu Ginóbili") announced his retirement from the NBA. Ginóbili played all his 16 seasons with the [San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs") franchise.[4]

### Free agency

[Free agency](/wiki/Free_agency "Free agency") negotiations began on July 1.
Players began signing on July 6 after the [July
moratorium](/wiki/July_moratorium "July moratorium") ended.

#### Off-season

  * On April 12, 2018, the [New York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks") fired head coach [Jeff Hornacek](/wiki/Jeff_Hornacek "Jeff Hornacek") after the team missed the playoffs.[5] In addition, associate head coach [Kurt Rambis](/wiki/Kurt_Rambis "Kurt Rambis") was also fired.
  * On April 12, 2018, the [Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic") fired head coach [Frank Vogel](/wiki/Frank_Vogel "Frank Vogel") after the team missed the playoffs.[6]
  * On April 13, 2018, the [Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte Hornets") fired head coach [Steve Clifford](/wiki/Steve_Clifford "Steve Clifford") after the team missed the playoffs.[7]
  * On April 25, 2018, the [Atlanta Hawks](/wiki/Atlanta_Hawks "Atlanta Hawks") and [Mike Budenholzer](/wiki/Mike_Budenholzer "Mike Budenholzer") had mutually agreed to part ways.[8]
  * On May 1, 2018, the [Memphis Grizzlies](/wiki/Memphis_Grizzlies "Memphis Grizzlies") announced that [J. B. Bickerstaff](/wiki/J._B._Bickerstaff "J. B. Bickerstaff") would become the new permanent head coach of the team.[9]
  * On May 2, 2018, the [Phoenix Suns](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns") hired [Igor Kokoškov](/wiki/Igor_Koko%C5%A1kov "Igor Kokoškov") as head coach.[10]
  * On May 7, 2018, the New York Knicks hired [David Fizdale](/wiki/David_Fizdale "David Fizdale") as head coach.[11]
  * On May 7, 2018, the [Detroit Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons") fired head coach [Stan Van Gundy](/wiki/Stan_Van_Gundy "Stan Van Gundy") after the team missed the playoffs for the second consecutive season.[12]
  * On May 10, 2018, the Charlotte Hornets hired [James Borrego](/wiki/James_Borrego "James Borrego") as head coach.[13]
  * On May 11, 2018, the [Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors") fired [Dwane Casey](/wiki/Dwane_Casey "Dwane Casey") after the team was swept by the [Cleveland Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") for the second consecutive time in the postseason.[14]
  * On May 11, 2018, the Atlanta Hawks hired [Lloyd Pierce](/wiki/Lloyd_Pierce "Lloyd Pierce") as head coach.[15]
  * On May 17, 2018, the [Milwaukee Bucks](/wiki/Milwaukee_Bucks "Milwaukee Bucks") hired [Mike Budenholzer](/wiki/Mike_Budenholzer "Mike Budenholzer") as head coach.[16]
  * On May 30, 2018, the Orlando Magic hired [Steve Clifford](/wiki/Steve_Clifford "Steve Clifford") as head coach.[17]
  * On June 11, 2018, the Detroit Pistons hired [Dwane Casey](/wiki/Dwane_Casey "Dwane Casey") as head coach.[18]
  * On June 14, 2018, the Toronto Raptors promoted assistant coach [Nick Nurse](/wiki/Nick_Nurse "Nick Nurse") as their head coach.[19]

## Preseason

The Preseason will begin on September 29 and will end on October 12.

### International games

The [Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors") will play two
preseason games in Canada first beginning with the [Portland Trail
Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail Blazers") in
[Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver") at the [Rogers
Arena](/wiki/Rogers_Arena "Rogers Arena") on September 29. And then the
[Brooklyn Nets](/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets "Brooklyn Nets") in
[Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal") at the [Bell Centre](/wiki/Bell_Centre
"Bell Centre") on October 10.[20]

The [Dallas Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") and the
[Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") will play
two preseason games in China at [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai") on
October 5 and [Shenzhen](/wiki/Shenzhen "Shenzhen") on October 8.[21]

## Regular season

The regular season will begin on October 16, 2018 and will end on April 10,
2019. The entire schedule was released on August 10, 2018.[22]

### International games

On June 20, 2018, the NBA announced that the [Washington
Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards") would play the [New
York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks") at [the O2
Arena](/wiki/The_O2_Arena "The O2 Arena") in [London](/wiki/London "London"),
United Kingdom on January 17, 2019.[23]

On August 7, 2018, the NBA announced that the [Orlando
Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic") would play two games at [Mexico
City Arena](/wiki/Mexico_City_Arena "Mexico City Arena") in [Mexico
City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"). They will play the [Chicago
Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago Bulls") on December 13, 2018, and they
will play the [Utah Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz") on December 15,
2018.[24]

## Arenas

  * This will be the [Golden State Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State Warriors")' final season at [Oracle Arena](/wiki/Oracle_Arena "Oracle Arena") in [Oakland](/wiki/Oakland,_California "Oakland, California"), before moving to the new [Chase Center](/wiki/Chase_Center_\(arena\) "Chase Center \(arena\)") in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"). The Warriors will play their final regular season game there in April 2019.[25]
  * This will be the [Milwaukee Bucks](/wiki/Milwaukee_Bucks "Milwaukee Bucks")' first season at the new [Fiserv Forum](/wiki/Fiserv_Forum "Fiserv Forum") after playing at the [Bradley Center](/wiki/Bradley_Center "Bradley Center") from 1988 to 2018. The Bucks will play their first game there in October 2018.[26][27]
  * The [Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors")' home arena was renamed [Scotiabank Arena](/wiki/Scotiabank_Arena "Scotiabank Arena") on July 1, 2018.[28][29]

## Media

This will be the third year of the current nine-year contracts with
[ABC](/wiki/NBA_on_ABC "NBA on ABC"), [ESPN](/wiki/NBA_on_ESPN "NBA on ESPN"),
[TNT](/wiki/NBA_on_TNT "NBA on TNT"), and [NBA TV](/wiki/NBA_TV "NBA
TV").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

## Uniforms

  * On June 6, 2018, the [Denver Nuggets](/wiki/Denver_Nuggets "Denver Nuggets") unveiled their new logos and uniforms to enter the 2018–19 season.[30][31]
  * On July 25, 2018, the [Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte Hornets") unveiled their new "Classic Edition" uniform to commemorate their 30th anniversary.[32]
  * On July 31, 2018, the [Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") unveiled their new uniforms to enter the 2018–19 season.[33]
  * On August 2, 2018, the [Memphis Grizzlies](/wiki/Memphis_Grizzlies "Memphis Grizzlies") unveiled their new logos and uniforms to enter the 2018–19 season.[34]
  * On August 8, 2018, the [Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic") unveiled their first "Classic Edition" uniform to commemorate their 30th anniversary.[35]
  * On August 16, 2018, the [Atlanta Hawks](/wiki/Atlanta_Hawks "Atlanta Hawks") unveiled their new "Classic Edition" uniform to commemorate their 50th anniversary since moving from [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis") to [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta").[36][37]

### Uniform sponsorships

In April 2016, the NBA announced that teams would be permitted to sign a
uniform sponsorship contract for the 2017–18 season.[38] Prior and during the
2017–18 season 21 teams signed a [uniform sponsorship
contract](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_NBA_season#Uniform_sponsorships "2017–18 NBA
season"). Before the 2018–19 season two more teams signed such contract:

  * [Memphis Grizzlies](/wiki/Memphis_Grizzlies "Memphis Grizzlies") – [FedEx](/wiki/FedEx "FedEx")[39]
  * [San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs") – [Frost Bank](/wiki/Frost_Bank "Frost Bank")[40]

As of August 22, 2018, seven teams have not signed a uniform sponsorship
contract: [Chicago Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago Bulls"), [Houston
Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets"), [Indiana
Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana Pacers"), [Oklahoma City
Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder"), [Phoenix
Suns](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns"), [Portland Trail
Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail Blazers"), and
[Washington Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards").
